conclusion: To determine the time during which there is an induced current in the frame, we will use the concept of electromagnetic induction.
According to Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction, an induced current occurs when there is a change in magnetic flux through a circuit.
Given: Side length of the square conductor frame: \( l \), Width of the magnetic field: \( d \), Speed of the frame: \( v \), The condition: \( l < d \)

premise: The frame starts to experience an induced current as soon as it enters the magnetic field.
conclusion: This starts at \( t = 0 \) when the left edge of the frame is at the edge of the magnetic field.

premise: The frame will fully enter the magnetic field when its right edge reaches the left edge of the magnetic field.
conclusion: Time taken to fully enter the magnetic field: \( t_1 = \frac{l}{v} \)

premise: The frame will start to exit the magnetic field when its left edge reaches the right edge of the magnetic field.
conclusion: Total time taken by the frame to completely cross the magnetic field: \( t_2 = \frac{d}{v} \)

premise: Total time taken by the frame to completely cross the magnetic field: \( t_2 = \frac{d}{v} \) and time taken to fully enter the magnetic field: \( t_1 = \frac{l}{v} \)
conclusion: Therefore, the time taken to fully exit the magnetic field: \( t_3 = t_2 - t_1 = \frac{d}{v} - \frac{l}{v} = \frac{d - l}{v} \)

premise: The frame is partially or fully within the magnetic field from the moment it starts entering until it finishes exiting.
The distance traveled during the process of the induced current is \( s = 2l \).
conclusion: The time during which there is an induced current in the frame is \( \frac{2l}{v} \).
